params.note: Rationale for generating organoids from SNRs: During early human embryonic development (18–19 d post-conception), gastrulation forms ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Ectodermal cells form neural plate (20–21 d), neural folds (22–23 d), and neural tube (25–26 d). Neural rosettes (SNRs) form spontaneously from PS cells in vitro during neural differentiation. Hypothesis: Isolated SNRs can generate predictably organized brain organoids with singular neural tube-like structure. Neural rosette-like structures are observed in brain tumors and may affect neuronal differentiation, migration, and maturation.

Neural induction uses dual-SMAD inhibition: BMP–SMAD1/5/8 inhibitor (dorsomorphin, 4 μM) and TGF-β–activin–NODAL–SMAD2/3 inhibitor (SB-431542, 10 μM) in neurobasal media with B27 supplement containing vitamin A. No Wnt inhibitors are used. FGF2 (10 ng/mL) and EGF (10 ng/mL) are added to stimulate neuroectodermal proliferation and radial glial identity.

Vitamin A in B27 is used to promote intermediate neural progenitor specification and corticogenesis, despite being a retinoic acid precursor. No significant expression of caudal markers (EN1, FOXA2, GBX2, PAX2, HOXA2, HOXA1) observed in SNR-derived organoids, suggesting retinoic acid concentration is insufficient for caudalization.

Endogenous morphogens (BMP7, SFRP1, FRZB) detected in SNR-derived organoids are relied upon to induce default neurodevelopmental program for telencephalic fate specification. Wnt/β-catenin signaling is preserved to support neural progenitor proliferation and dorsal telencephalic patterning.

Preliminary experiments show that omission of FGF2 impairs neural rosette formation, limits organoid growth, and increases cell death. Neural rosettes typically emerge at 6–8 days after initiation of EGF/FGF2 treatment.

Each neural rosette (NR) is a 3D multicellular structure with neuroepithelial and radial glial cells radially distributed around a central lumen. NR cells undergo interkinetic nuclear migration between basal and apical regions.
